channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: Dead bodies are piling up on gurneys in hospital hallways as Hong Kong’s health system is overloaded by its biggest coronavirus outbreak of the pandemic. More than 400 people died from Covid-19 last week, the latest official statistics show. https://t.co/7CksISWudx

In the basement shelter of the Okhmadet Children’s Hospital in Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, women tended to their sick children as Russian forces closed in on the city. https://t.co/rzssfVY36T https://t.co/mFo2Jw9kOv

Shell, Europe’s largest oil company, said Monday it would exit four oil and gas joint ventures with Gazprom, the Russian gas giant, valued at about $3 billion. The decision is a further blow to Russia and its oil industry.
Follow live updates: https://t.co/q6tUKjULGj

In a call with President Vladimir Putin of Russia that lasted an hour and a half, President Emmanuel Macron of France on Monday urged for an immediate cease-fire and an end to all attacks on civilians and essential infrastructure in Ukraine. https://t.co/x3im17fYbD

New satellite images show Russian ground forces — a convoy stretched out over at least 17 miles — within 30 miles of Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv. The line of vehicles is so extensive that it was not entirely captured in Monday’s satellite imagery. https://t.co/rty0sb4bJM

In Opinion
“Where once Russia and other autocracies were seen as anti-democratic, they have now become symbols of U.S. conservatism — a mirror for the right-wing worldview,” writes Emily Tamkin, an author and journalist, in a guest essay. https://t.co/73sH579bEU

In a passionate speech on Monday, President Volodymyr Zelensky urged the EU to admit Ukraine immediately: “Our goal is to stand alongside all Europeans and, most importantly, to stand on their level.” https://t.co/xgMrGyltLZ https://t.co/1pRzZTgnuy

Breaking News: FIFA will ban Russia and its teams, ejecting the country from qualifying for the 2022 World Cup only weeks before it was to play for one of Europe’s final places in the tournament. UEFA will join FIFA in issuing and honoring the ban. https://t.co/TVD3uh1oUY https://t.co/cqv9ZvVv7h

Many Ukrainians and Russians, because of their countries’ intertwined history, have relatives from both sides of the border who are now standing on opposite sides of the frontline. It has raised fears that family members will harm each other in battle. https://t.co/GDvqGrkJwb https://t.co/YytITjT0QK

President Volodymyr Zelensky urged the European Union on Monday to grant Ukraine immediate accession to the bloc. “Europeans are aware that our soldiers are fighting for our country and, consequently, for the whole of Europe," he said. https://t.co/ahq2BzchbF https://t.co/Az0OFwgK67

As more people arrive in Lviv, a city in western Ukraine, from the east, the stories they share are growing increasingly dire, our reporter on the ground writes. The train station has filled with people trying to flee the country from Russia's attacks. https://t.co/EIJJgL9QSg https://t.co/wFPKb6pBIJ

Breaking News: Switzerland will freeze Russian assets, including those of President Vladimir Putin, setting aside its long tradition of neutrality. The country is a favorite destination for Russian money.
Follow our updates. https://t.co/gBiE3t0l4m

The dangers of climate change are mounting so rapidly that they could soon overwhelm our ability to adapt, a UN report found. Written by 270 researchers from 67 countries, it is the most detailed look yet at the threats posed by global warming. https://t.co/v6O42BFJRv https://t.co/6RzmiaoObk

Breaking News: The U.S. escalated sanctions with a freeze on Russian central bank assets. The sanctions will limit Russia’s ability to finance its “destabilizing activities,” Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said.
Follow our updates. https://t.co/Xa8bjC71f7

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged the EU to grant his country immediate membership of the bloc.
He also had a message for Russian troops in Ukraine: “Abandon your military equipment and leave,” he said. “Save your lives. Leave.” https://t.co/JGBMQM762D https://t.co/yZI2TmjuGw

The pediatrics ward of a children’s hospital in Kyiv was relocated to the hospital’s basement. Women watched over their babies in the bomb shelter as fighting continued in Ukraine. https://t.co/ybG1HTNSS3 https://t.co/QvhVTfLJIs

Ukraine accused Russian forces of launching rockets on a residential neighborhood in Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second largest city, killing dozens of civilians, just as Ukrainian and Russian officials were preparing to meet for talks. https://t.co/G9UCH5H0dv

The Metropolitan Opera will no longer engage with performers or other institutions that have voiced support for President Vladimir Putin of Russia, the company said. https://t.co/3AJKNLUYmN https://t.co/p5dbjJ6cim

As delegations from Ukraine and Russia met for talks in Belarus, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine called for the EU to grant his country immediate membership. https://t.co/61XoYtrSS1 https://t.co/eI3cIWpd0H

Thousands of people gathered at rallies across the U.S. on Sunday in a show of support for Ukraine. Many waved blue and yellow Ukrainian flags, sang patriotic songs and shouted chants against President Vladimir Putin of Russia. https://t.co/DSnO1Xxdq4 https://t.co/p0DZ8U7xem

Breaking News: The dangers of climate change are mounting so rapidly that they could soon overwhelm our ability to adapt, a UN report found.
The effects of climate change are “much more widespread and much more negative than expected,” one researcher said.https://t.co/qGWhFe6Jev

The UN Human Rights Council brushed aside Russian objections and accepted a request from Ukraine for an urgent debate on Russia’s invasion.
Ukraine is expected to call for a team of human rights experts to monitor and report on abuses and war crimes. https://t.co/VkdUUwsAf8

Ukrainian officials have arrived on the Ukraine-Belarus border for talks with Russia.
“The key issue of the talks is an immediate ceasefire and the withdrawal of troops from Ukraine,” President Volodymyr Zelensky’s office said in a statement. https://t.co/wnrp4Bm71Z https://t.co/nxZDoMisXb

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine called for the EU to grant his country immediate membership. “Our goal is to be together with all Europeans and, most importantly, to be on an equal footing,” he said.
Follow our updates on the Ukraine crisis. https://t.co/AVwrMs4VpH

Britain banned its financial institutions from conducting transactions with the Russian central bank as well as its foreign ministry and sovereign wealth fund.
“Putin must fail,” Prime Minister Boris Johnson said in a tweet. https://t.co/SmnsBT5tdJ

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine agreed to talk with Russia, but said he feared it would not result in peace as Russian forces massed outside Kyiv.
Follow live updates. https://t.co/XOyEGuxq8o

The true extent of President Vladimir Putin of Russia's wealth remains maddeningly opaque, even as billions of dollars have sluiced through the accounts of his close friends, and luxury properties have been connected to family members. https://t.co/nSml8Rf9qr

Prime Minister Viktor Orban's hard-line refugee policy normally would have made it impossible for so many of the Ukrainians entering Hungary to get international protection. But Russia's invasion forced him to reverse himself as an election looms. https://t.co/WOCYkE3WaK

The value of Russia’s currency has plunged, falling by more than 30% against the dollar after the U.S., European countries and other nations excluded some Russian banks from international transactions by removing them from SWIFT. https://t.co/hUv7tM7nL6 https://t.co/Ty0krdZJQ7

Facebook's parent company, Meta, said that it had shut down influence and hacking campaigns targeting Ukraine. The efforts were tied to people in Russia and Ukraine, as well as to a hacking group thought to be affiliated with Belarus, Meta executives said. https://t.co/D7gnT01OYu

Israel is a strong ally of the U.S., and its leaders have a good relationship with Volodymyr Zelensky, Ukraine’s Jewish president. But Israel also doesn’t want to provoke Russia. https://t.co/VcG4B2SCkp
As the world overwhelmingly condemns Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the Chinese internet, for the most part, is pro-Russia, pro-war and pro-Putin. https://t.co/EvJAnq3HjR

Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia said his government would contribute $3 million toward the supply of nonlethal military equipment and medical supplies to Ukraine through a fund set up by NATO. https://t.co/fP1SS0git5
The Metropolitan Opera will no longer engage with performers or other institutions that have voiced support for President Vladimir Putin of Russia, the company said. https://t.co/vIiPadi320
Germany announced it would increase its military spending and help arm Ukrainians in an about-face from its decades-long defense policy. https://t.co/PySgPvxnjf
When Russia declared its nuclear forces were in “special combat readiness,” the U.S. could have gone on high alert. It chose to de-escalate. https://t.co/6nNmYrLqKJ
Ex-Attorney General William Barr’s memoir blamed Donald Trump for taking his stolen election claim to “absurd lengths,” causing the Jan. 6 riot. https://t.co/cDyS0yVdg0

FIFA has agreed on a range of measures that would take effect for Russia’s crucial World Cup qualifying playoff next month. But the proposals — including a ban on Russia's name and flag — exclude the all-out ban on Russia’s national team. https://t.co/5OsZty6zdu

Video verified by The New York Times shows an oil depot ablaze on the southern outskirts of Kyiv on Feb. 27. A Ukrainian official said that Russian forces struck the depot. https://t.co/47C5KAcp2x https://t.co/RHedKnkw4w

"I just want to live in our country, and that's all." Julia, a teacher and Ukrainian volunteer, wept as she waited to be deployed to fight Russian troops around Kyiv on Saturday. "It's awful," she said. https://t.co/SbwaUeefty https://t.co/cBwz7Tsvlh

A musician who traded his guitar for a rifle: "I’m no longer a musician. I’m a soldier now."
A 15-year-old who joined a group preparing bottles for firebombs: "It’s my duty."
Even in villages so far untouched by Russia, Ukrainians are preparing to fight. https://t.co/NHdzxIwdgh

In 2014, he joined the Ukrainian Army after Russian-backed separatists seized areas in the east. Now, Oleksandr Bilyy, 39, is headed back to Ukraine — to fight the Russians who invaded his country. “Nothing will change if I stay in my house,” he said. https://t.co/AjrrfKCjYa https://t.co/TgjHAR0gGR

Alexei Ratmansky, the New York-based choreographer, was working on a new ballet for the Bolshoi when Russia invaded Ukraine. Ratmansky, who grew up in Kyiv, left Moscow and says he doubts he'd return to Russia to work “if Putin is still president.” https://t.co/CLHFYnQEJP

The EU's executive arm will ask member nations to grant temporary asylum to all Ukrainians coming to the bloc for up to three years. More than 300,000 people have already fled Ukraine, and there could be four million more, officials said. https://t.co/TZXfedlsT8

In cities and towns in Central Ukraine that have not yet heard the boom of Russian artillery fire, residents spent the weekend preparing furiously for the possibility of an attack. https://t.co/Y2yTgqhk91 https://t.co/dbp6QKR8q7

Norway’s sovereign wealth fund, a $1.3 trillion fund, is freezing its assets in Russia and plans to divest from the Russian market, a spokeswoman said Sunday. Its Russian investments equaled 0.2% of the fund. https://t.co/jxedHL4aRY

“I made the decision to come back to Ukraine and fight.” While tens of thousands of Ukrainians have sought safety in neighboring countries, some have returned from abroad to fight against the Russian invasion and reunite with family members. https://t.co/Y0HLEviFq5 https://t.co/ohnLp4b5qh

“I am so proud of our people,” said Oksana Mudryk, the mayor of a village about 140 miles away from Kyiv. "I thought maybe three guys at most would come to patrol with me. But in one day after the war started in Kyiv, I have signed up more than 30 people.” https://t.co/FEcsneIeZN
New: The UN Security Council will meet on Sunday at 3 p.m. Eastern to call for an emergency special session of the General Assembly on the war in Ukraine. https://t.co/oYpr0ri2eK

"I can't just stay in Poland and let Russians destroy our independence." While tens of thousands of Ukrainians have sought safety in neighboring countries, some returned from abroad to fight against the Russian invasion. Watch some of them explain why. https://t.co/MzLpBZ5obz
